So, the breakdown I gave on the construction cost increase is on REX and MEP and Louisiana were geared toward the Q2 to Q3 change, rather than the change from January.

And Rich you commented on the impact of – or the potential impact of commodity prices. Could you also just comment on the potential impact of the lower oil prices on what might be happening up in Canada as far as the oil sands?

Yves, I think, it seems to be that most of particularly the larger players up there are still very intent on carrying out their oil sands projects, even in the face of they've experienced escalation costs, and clearly a difference in pricing now. And I would expect that we've always said, we would haircut some of these dramatic growth projections that some people have come up with for Canada. But I think any way you cut it, you're still going to see a substantial and large increase in the amount of production that's coming out of the oil sands.

But, yeah, I think lower oil prices will certainly have some impact on it. But I think that, so many of these projects are so far along now that they really don't have any choice but to finish them up, I think. And obviously the various joint ventures and contracts signed with refineries in the U.S. that are retrofitting to accommodate the heavier oil just increases both the desire and the contractual necessity of finishing some of these projects.

But we'll continue to watch it. As you know, we're finished or will be by the end of this month with our expansion on Trans Mountain. We will be at 300,000 barrels a day capacity coming over to the lower mainland. And actually right now in our numbers, we've had very good volumes down into Washington State. A part of that goes out over the water from our facility in Vancouver Harbor. Part of it gets consumed in the lower mainland, and then a significant part goes down to Washington State. And we've actually, I don't know how much of a long term trend this is, but we've actually seen the last two months some of the highest volumes going in to Washington state that we've seen at any time since we owned that asset.
So, what that's a result of, I don't know. But, clearly we're seeing a lot of demand for it and a lot of demand coming over the water, also.

I have just two last ones. Rich, you also went over the credit worthiness of the guys on Rockies Express and Mid Continent. When you look at the Fayetteville expansion or any other type of stuff, are you worried at all about counterparty risk, and are you contemplating, are you getting right now – that hasn't even been built yet, but letters of credit, can you just – has the world changed enough that you're sort of worried about future projects and credit quality?

I think we're always worried about credit quality in any environment. And we have, and I really can't go into details on any of the contracts. But on virtually all of our contracts across our pipelines unless it's with very few exceptions, we do have letters of credit to back up in certain events on a number of our projects, including Fayetteville.

The only thing, I'll add to that is we do get credit protection in all instances. Especially on FERC regulated pipelines, there are restrictions on what we can get, and so we live within the FERC guidelines on that approach. And then for these projects, I mean, Fayetteville is a good example, I mean, you look beyond that as well, and say what actually would happen if a counterparty got in trouble? Is this gas still going to be produced, and if it's going to be produced it's quite likely going to have to use this pipeline capacity, which means in that event, your contract likely get affirmed. But I'm not saying that's always the case. I'm saying we go to that level of analysis as we're evaluating this.

Before we contract to build a pipeline away from a specific area we look at what the overall formation is going to produce, what the cost structure of that is, and what the kind of market clearing price is, and of course, so much of this money that the producers are spending is up front in terms of leasehold costs, so actually the F&P costs in a lot of cases are pretty minor, not minor, but pretty slight compared to the pricing, even in today's market.

Okay. And here's the last one, which you may or may not want to answer. But in terms of acquisition opportunities or JV opportunities that may come your way, are any of these significant step-out type of transactions as opposed to the singles and doubles that you hit pretty well?

You're right, I wouldn't want to comment on that. Let me just say that we'd be very careful before we did anything. And of course one way of doing that is if you did something, you might do something for equity. So it would be self-financing from a going forward standpoint. But it would just depend on the circumstances; we would be very careful before we did anything. But there are certainly opportunities out there.
Got it. Thank you.
Thank you, Yves.
And our next question comes from Ross Payne with Wachovia.
Hey, Ross. How're you doing?
Hey, guys. First question is, can you tell us how much of the quarter's crude production was hedged, and where you are for the rest of the year and for '09?
Sure. Park?

Yeah. I mean, the crude production for 2008 is essentially low 90s percent hedge, 93% approximately. And '09, we're about 82% hedge. Now, that's crude only, that doesn't include NGLs, and the denominator.

Okay. All right. Also, just looking at your most recent expansion program with ETP, looking at the mileage and the cost, it looks like it's around 7 billion a mile. Is that, I guess, where we are currently because I'm accustomed to seeing things more in the three, maybe four range.
Steve.

Well what we've tried to do in the Fayetteville project is really pulled in our full experience with the cost increases experienced on our other projects and frankly, that added some. So what you're seeing is, hopefully, something that has some margins for error in it. But it does reflect the worst of what we've seen so far in the pipeline construction arena.

Okay. And finally, if I can kind of get a number on where REX debt is also looking; if you could comment on S&P's actions here. It's kind of interesting that on the second of the month they came out to talk about your Fayetteville expansion and said if you're going to be over 4.5 times debt to EBITDA, probably inclusive of REX debt, if they would look at a negative outlook and they obviously moved much quicker. If you just give some color on your thought as to why they did move as quick; and also if you can give us the REX debt number, thanks.

The REX debt number is we got 1.9 billion of debt out there. In terms of longer term debt, there's 600 of floater, 1.3 billion of long-term and then outstanding on the credit facility is about $1 billion dollars.
Okay. So that's – was that 1.3 plus 600 plus one?
Yeah. Almost $3 billion.

And then we put – and again these are on basis and then within REX to date the partners have contributed about $1 billion of equity into the project. So that's how you get to Rich's number earlier of roughly $4 billion in REX.
All right. And any comments on the rating agencies?
I think as I said before it was prompted by the announcement around the REX delay. And I didn't know that we have anything to add to the comments before.

Okay. And Park, when you guys talk about the debt number, given that the rating agencies are going to be looking at this, you're including the REX EBITDA in your earnings, if you could maybe give us what the debt numbers are at REX just when you're going through that, that would be helpful for us, thanks.
The numbers that we give you at REX is after interest expense. All we do is we take our net income or equity and our earnings and we add back our DD&A. We are not adding back the interest expense.
Okay.

I think it's better to look at it without including the REX debt. So what we're trying to give you, when we talk about our distributable cash flow number, is what we actually expect to receive out of REX in a distribution. And so that's why we add back the DD&A and we take off this remaining CapEx.
Sure.
It's after the REX debt is already serviced.

Right. I understand that. Being on the debt side, we're just trying to look at what the rating agencies are looking at from a total debt to EBITDA standpoint and inclusive of REX. That's why I was asking for that.

I understand that they are looking at that and we'll have some more conversations with S&P about that. Rockies Express is an investment grade rated entity. It supports its own debt and we expect that it will going forward. The $1.3 billion on it is non-recourse to us. We expect that there will be additional debt on it that's non-recourse to us. I tend to think that's consistent with their understanding.
All right. Okay. Thanks guys.
Thank you, Ross.
And our next question comes from Burt Zimmerman with Principal Global. Sir, your line is open.
Thank you. Good afternoon guys.
Good afternoon.
I just had a quick question. You mentioned what your credit facility was going to look like at the end of the year. Could you just quickly run through what those credit facilities have available now?

Yeah. And today at KMP we have in excess of 800 million, we have almost 900 million at REX, we have about 650 million at MEP. And let me just say, in case somebody's asked this, those are all net of any commitment from Lehman which was very small, about 3% of our total lines came from Lehman. But we've netted those out even though I think in the end Barkley's may elect to take part of those, but at this time that's not been done. And so we've been, I think, conservative there and just netted off, it's very minor as I said, a little over 3% of the total commitments is from Lehman. But we have netted that out and the numbers we're giving you are without that.
Okay. So you have 800 million left on your KMP revolver now and you expect to have 600 million at the end of the year?
We expect more, closer to 650, yeah.
Okay. So you're only going to draw another 150 it sounds like for the rest of the year?
We have a little over 800, and we're going to be a little under 650. So yeah, 170 in that range.
Okay. All right. Thanks a lot.
And our next question comes from Rajul Agerwal with Marathon Asset Management . Sir, your line is open.
Yeah, Rajul (1:41:27.
Hi, thanks for taking my second set of questions. Just on the facility, on that 600 million floater that I think are recourse to you on the Rockies Express, how do you plan to tackle that?
We expect to refinance it, and then of course there will be equity contributions coming from the partners as well.
So you think you will be from between now and August of '09 issuing 600 million that ForEx?
Yeah, there's a reasonable chance for that.
Got it. The reason I'm asking, I mean, given what is happening in the credit market you haven't given a thought to use the prior facility to finance it?
Well, we could do that as well.
Got it. At what point does the credit facility become too tight for the ongoing CapEx at REX itself, or are you comfortable with the availability right now you have of 900 million at that facility?
I mean, we'll look at that when we look at 2009 and see how the CapEx is going to flow.
Got it. And in terms of your own maturity, the 250 that you have in '09, how do you plan to refi that?
Well, either refinance it with long-term debt, or we'll refinance it using the credit facility, or we'll issue equity.
Thank you.
I'm showing no further questions at this time.

All right. Mary , thank you very much. It's been a long call. Again, as I always say if you have additional questions feel free to call Kim, or any of the rest of our people and we'll try to answer any and all questions that you may have. I appreciate your patience for a long call and we'll talk again soon.
